content: The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" establishes governmentwide standards for program and project management for executive agencies. The Deputy Director for Management is responsible for overseeing the implementation of these standards. The Director, Deputy Director for Management, or designee shall adopt governmentwide standards, policies, and guidelines for program and project management for executive agencies, oversee implementation, chair the Program Management Policy Council, and establish standards and policies consistent with widely accepted standards. The Director, Deputy Director for Management, or designee shall chair the Program Management Policy Council, establish standards for executive agencies, engage with the private sector for best practices, conduct portfolio reviews for high-risk programs annually. The Program Management Policy Council, chaired by the Director, Deputy Director for Management, or designee, establishes standards for executive agencies, engages with the private sector for best practices, and conducts annual portfolio reviews for high-risk programs. Additionally, they are required to establish a 5-year strategic plan for program and project management. The Program Management Policy Council, chaired by the Director, establishes standards for executive agencies, engages with the private sector for best practices, and conducts annual portfolio reviews for high-risk programs. A 5-year strategic plan for program and project management must be established. The Department of Defense is exempt from certain provisions if they are similar to existing policies. The Deputy Director for Management must finalize standards, policies, and guidelines within a year of the Act's enactment. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget must issue standards, policies, and guidelines related to program management within 1 year of the Act's enactment. Regulations must be finalized within 90 days after the issuance of the standards. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Program Management Policy Council, must issue regulations within 90 days to implement the requirements of section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget will issue regulations to implement section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. Additionally, each agency must designate a senior executive as a Program Management Improvement Officer. The head of each agency must designate a senior executive as the Program Management Improvement Officer. This officer will implement program management policies and develop strategies to enhance the role of program managers within the agency. The Program Management Improvement Officer must implement agency policies and develop strategies to enhance program managers' roles, including providing enhanced training opportunities. The Program Management Improvement Officer must provide training in relevant competencies for program and project managers in the private sector, focusing on cost containment for large projects and programs. The Program Management Improvement Officer aims to mentor current and future program managers, improve career paths, encourage recruitment of qualified individuals, share best practices, and provide templates for program management enhancement. The Program Management Improvement Officer focuses on mentoring program managers, enhancing career paths, recruiting qualified individuals, sharing best practices, and providing templates for program management improvement. This subsection does not apply to the Department of Defense if similar provisions exist in chapter 87 of title 10. The Program Management Improvement Officer focuses on mentoring program managers, enhancing career paths, recruiting qualified individuals, sharing best practices, and providing templates for program management improvement. The Department of Defense is exempt from this subsection if similar provisions are in chapter 87 of title 10. A Program Management Policy Council is established in the Office of Management and Budget. The Program Management Policy Council, established in the Office of Management and Budget, serves as the main interagency forum for improving agency practices in program and project management. It advises the Deputy Director for Management and reviews high-risk programs identified by the General Accountability Office. The Program Management Policy Council advises the Deputy Director for Management on high-risk programs and discusses workforce development, program management policy, and agency challenges. The Program Management Policy Council advises on career development, workforce needs, policy for program management improvement, and challenges in program management across agencies. They also provide guidance on developing governmentwide standards for program management transparency and review information on the Office of Management and Budget's website. The Program Management Policy Council advises on career development, workforce needs, program management improvement policy, and governmentwide standards. The Council's membership includes five members from the Office of Management and Budget. The Program Management Policy Council advises on career development, workforce needs, program management improvement policy, and governmentwide standards. The Council's membership includes five members from the Office of Management and Budget, such as the Deputy Director for Management, the Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, the Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy, the Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, and the Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management. The Program Management Policy Council includes the Program Management Improvement Officer from each agency and other designated federal employees. The Chairperson is the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, with a Vice Chairperson elected by members for a term of up to 1 year. The Chairperson of the Program Management Policy Council is the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget. A Vice Chairperson is elected by members for a term of up to 1 year. The Chairperson presides over meetings, sets the agenda, directs the work of the Council, and may establish subgroups. The Council must meet at least twice per fiscal year and can meet at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of members. The Program Management Policy Council must meet at least twice per fiscal year and can convene at the Chairperson's or majority members' call. Agency heads with Project Management Improvement Officers on the Council must provide administrative support as requested by the Chairperson. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with designated Program Management Improvement Officers, must submit a report within one year of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, along with designated Program Management Improvement Officers, must submit a report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment containing the strategy developed under section 1126(a)(2)(B) of title 31, United States Code. The term "agency" in this subsection refers to all agencies described in section 901(b) of title 31, United States Code, excluding the Department of Defense. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, must issue regulations within 180 days of the issuance of standards, policies, and guidelines under section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. These regulations will identify key skills and competencies needed for program and project management personnel. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will issue regulations to identify key skills and competencies for program and project managers, establish a new job series or update an existing one, and create a new career path for managers within agencies. The Government Accountability Office will issue a report on the effectiveness of policies for improving Federal program and project management, including standards, policies, and guidelines established under section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. The report will examine the effectiveness of standards, policies, and guidelines for program and project management, the 5-year strategic plan, Program Management Improvement Officers, and the Program Management Policy Council as outlined in title 31, United States Code. The Program Management Improvement Officers and Program Management Policy Council are designated under title 31, United States Code.
